questions.title: What is Software?

options.title: Hardware Components.
A set of instructions that tell a computer what to do.
Physical devices such as keyboards and mice.

questions.title: What is an example of everyday Software the you use?

options.title: Microsoft Word.
A Chair.
A Refrigerator.

questions.title: Explain the difference between System Software and Application Software

options.title: System software manages computer hardware, while application software performs specific tasks.
Application software controls system hardware.
Both are the same thing.

questions.title: What is the role of a compiler in software development?

options.title: It generates electricity for computers.
It translates high-level programming code into machine code.
It designs user interfaces.

questions.title: Describe the difference between procedural programming and object-oriented programming.

options.title: They are identical concepts.
Procedural focuses on functions, while object-oriented focuses on objects and classes.
Object-Oriented programming is an outdated methodology.

questions.title: How does garbage collection work in programming languages and why is it important?

options.title: Garbage collection refers to recycling paper in the office.
It manages memory by automatically reclaiming unused resources, improving efficiency.
Garbage collection is irrelevant in modern programming languages.

questions.title: Explain the concept of design patterns in Software Development.

options.title: Templates used for graphic design.
A tool for debugging code.
Best practices and reuseable solutions to common problems in Software Design.

questions.title: Discuss the benefits and challenges of using microservices architecture in Software Development.

options.title: Microservices are too complex and offer no benefits.
They improve scalability and enable independent deployment, but may introduce complexity.
Microservices architecture is only suitable for small projects.

questions.title: What is the significance of DevOps in the software development lifecycle?

options.title: DevOps is trendy buzzword with no real impact.
DevOps enhances collaboration between development and operations, streamlining they development lifecycle.
DevOps is only relevant for large enterprises.

questions.title: Compare and contrast static and dynamic code analysis techniques, highlighting their importance in ensuring Software Security.

options.title: Static analysis focuses on code behaviour, while dynamic analysis examines code structure.
Both techniques are unnecessary for ensuring Software Security.
Static analysis reviews code with executing it, while dynamic analysis assesses code during runtime for vulnerabilities.

questions.title: What is an Algorithm?

options.title: A software bug.
A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem
Computer memory.

questions.title: Which of the following is not an example of an Algorithm?

options.title: Making a sandwich.
Finding the maximum value in an array.
Sorting a list of numbers.

questions.title: What is the time complexity of an Algorithm?

options.title: The maount of time it takes to write an Algorithm.
The amount of time it takes for the Algorithm to run in terms of input size.
The number of steps in the Algorithm

questions.title: Which sorting Algorithm has teh best average-case time complexity?

options.title: Quick Sort
Bubble Sort
Insertion Sort

questions.title: What is the concept of (Big-O) notation used for in algorithm analysis?

options.title: Describing the upper bound of an algorithm's growth rate.
Representing the size of input data.
Calculating the average execution time of an algorithm.

questions.title: In algorithm design, what is the (greedy) approach?

options.title: Choosing the most efficient algorithm.
Making locally optimal choices at each stage with the hope of finding a global optimum
Always choosing the longest path in a graph.

questions.title: What is the difference between dynamic programming and divde and conquer?

options.title: They are the same concept.
Dynamic programming breaks down a problem intro smaller sub-problems and solves each only once, whiel divide and conquer may solve the same sub-problem multiple times.
Divide and conquer is only suitable for small-scale problems.

questions.title: Explain the concept of NP-Completeness in algorithmic complexity theory.

options.title: The complexity of non-polynomial time algorithms.
A class of problems for which a solution can be verified quickly, but a solution can't be found quickly
The simplicity of problems that can be solved in polynomial time

questions.title: What is the significance of the P vs. NP problem in theoretical computer science?

options.title: It defines the difference between parallel and non-parallel algorithms.
It determines the speed of computer processors.
It explores the relationship between polynomial time and non-polynomial time algorithms.

questions.title: In the context of algorithms, what is quantum computing's potential impact on problem-solving?

options.title: Quantum computers can solve certain problems exponentially faster than classical computers.
Quantum computing has no impact on algorithmic complexity.
Quantum computing only works for simple algorithms.

questions.title: What is the main concept of object-oriented programming (OOP)?

options.title: Algorithms
Objects and classes
Data structures

questions.title: Which OOP principle is related to bundling data and methods that operate on the data into a single unit?

options.title: Polymorphism.
Encapsulation.
Inheritance.

questions.title: What is the purpose of inheritance in OOP?

options.title: To define the relationship between objects and classes.
To reuse code and create a hierarchy of classes.
To allow multiple classes to be combined into one.

questions.title: What is polymorphism in OOP?

options.title: The ability of a function to take different forms or behave differently based on the input.
The ability of a class to have multiple constructors.
The process of creating multiple instances of a class.

questions.title: What is a virtual function in C++??

options.title: A function that doesn't have a body
A function that can only be called once
A function that can be overridden in a derived class

questions.title: In OOP, what is composition?

options.title: A design principle that promotes code reuse by combining objects.
A way to achieve multiple inheritance.
A technique for hiding the implementation details of a class.

questions.title: What is the difference between abstraction and encapsulation in OOP?

options.title: Abstraction is the bundling of data and methods, while encapsulation is a way to hide the complexity of the implementation.
Abstraction and encapsulation are synonymous in OOP.
Abstraction is a way to hide the complexity of the implementation, while encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods.

questions.title: How does the concept of (interfaces) contribute to achieving multiple inheritance in some programming languages?

options.title: By allowing a class to inherit from multiple classes.
By enabling the creation of abstract classes.
By defining a contract for a set of methods that a class must implement.

questions.title: What are the SOLID principles in object-oriented design?

options.title: Guidelines for naming variables and functions in object-oriented programming.
The fundamental data types used in OOP languages.
A set of five design principles for writing maintainable and scalable software.

questions.title: In OOP, what is the difference between shallow copy and deep copy?

options.title: Shallow copy duplicates the entire object, while deep copy duplicates only the references.
Shallow copy and deep copy refer to the same concept in OOP.
Shallow copy duplicates only the references, while deep copy duplicates the actual objects.

questions.title: What is the purpose of software requirement analysis?

options.title: To write the code for the software.
To gather, document, and understand the needs and constraints of the users and stakeholders.
To design the user interface of the software.

questions.title: What is a user story in the context of requirement analysis?

options.title: A narrative description of a software feature from the user's perspective.
A detailed technical specification.
A summary of project milestones.

questions.title: What is the difference between functional and non-functional requirements?

options.title: Functional requirements define what the system should do, while non-functional requirements define how well the system should do it.
Functional requirements relate to hardware, while non-functional requirements relate to software.
Functional requirements are specific to the user interface, while non-functional requirements relate to the overall system architecture.

questions.title: What is the purpose of a use case in requirement analysis?

options.title: To document the testing scenarios.
To describe how a system interacts with external entities.
To outline the software development timeline.

questions.title: What is the significance of traceability in requirement analysis?

options.title: It ensures that the requirements can be traced back to the project manager.
It establishes a link between requirements and other project artifacts, ensuring that changes are managed effectively.
It helps in the design phase of the software development life cycle.

questions.title: What is the role of a prototype in requirement analysis?

options.title: To serve as the final version of the software.
To provide a visual representation of the software to gather feedback and validate requirements.
To generate code automatically based on the requirements document.

questions.title: What is the Kano model used for in requirement analysis?

options.title: It assesses the risk associated with each requirement.
It prioritizes requirements based on their business value.
It classifies customer preferences into categories such as basic, performance, and excitement.

questions.title: Explain the concept of the Moscow method in prioritizing requirements.

options.title: It classifies requirements into four categories: Must-haves, Should-haves, Could-haves, and Won't-haves.
It evaluates requirements based on monetary value.
It categorizes requirements into technical and non-technical aspects.

questions.title: What is the role of a Business Analyst in software requirement analysis?

options.title: To write the code for the software.
To manage the project schedule.
To act as a liaison between business stakeholders and the development team, gathering and analysing requirements.

questions.title: How does the concept of (agile) impact software requirement analysis?

options.title: Agile methods do not emphasize requirements; they focus solely on coding and testing.
Agile promotes iterative and collaborative approaches to requirement analysis, allowing for changes throughout the development process.
Agile methods are only applicable to large-scale projects.

questions.title: What is a data structure?

options.title: A method for writing code
A format for database tables
An arrangement of data elements that allows for efficient operations

questions.title: Which of the following is an example of a linear data structure?

options.title: Binary tree
Linked list
Hash table

questions.title: What is the time complexity of searching an element in a sorted array using binary search?

options.title: O(n)
O(log n)

questions.title: In the context of trees, what is the height of a binary tree with n nodes in the best case?

options.title: O(log n)
O(n)

questions.title: What is the main advantage of using a hash table for data storage?

options.title: Efficient for range queries
Constant time complexity for all operations
Effective for hierarchical data representation

questions.title: What is the concept of amortised analysis in the context of data structures?

options.title: Analysing the worst-case time complexity of an algorithm
Evaluating the average-case time complexity over multiple operations
Assessing the best-case time complexity of a data structure

questions.title: Explain the difference between a stack and a queue data structure.

options.title: A stack follows LIFO (Last In, First Out) order, while a queue follows FIFO (First In, First Out) order.
A stack follows FIFO order, while a queue follows LIFO order.
Both stack and queue follow the same order of operations.

questions.title: What is the purpose of a self-balancing binary search tree, such as AVL or Red-Black Tree?

options.title: To ensure constant time complexity for all operations
To automatically adjust its structure to maintain balance, optimising for efficient search and retrieval
To provide a linear data structure for quick insertion and deletion

questions.title: What is the difference between a graph and a tree in data structures?

options.title: A graph is always cyclic, while a tree is acyclic.
A graph is a linear structure, while a tree is a hierarchical structure.
Both terms refer to the same data structure.

questions.title: Explain the concept of dynamic programming in the context of data structures.

options.title: It is a programming paradigm for writing code in a flexible, dynamic manner.
It is a method for optimizing database queries.
It is a technique for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler, overlapping subproblems.

questions.title: What does CPU stand for?

options.title: Central Processing Unit
Central Peripheral Unit
Central Power Unit

questions.title: Which component stores data temporarily for the CPU to quickly access?

options.title: RAM (Random Access Memory)
ROM (Read-Only Memory)
HDD (Hard Disk Drive)

questions.title: What is the role of the ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) in a CPU?

options.title: Managing memory operations
Performing arithmetic and logical operations
Controlling input and output devices

questions.title: What is the purpose of a cache memory in a computer system?

options.title: To store the operating system
To temporarily store frequently accessed data for faster retrieval
To manage input/output operations

questions.title: What is pipelining in computer architecture?

options.title: A technique for parallel processing
A type of memory organization
The process of connecting multiple computers in a network

questions.title: What is the Von Neumann architecture?

options.title: A type of computer memory
An architecture where data and instructions share the same memory space
A specific type of CPU

questions.title: Explain the concept of RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computing) architecture.

options.title: It uses a large set of instructions for complex operations
It focuses on a small set of simple instructions to improve efficiency
It is a type of parallel processing architecture

questions.title: What is the role of the MMU (Memory Management Unit) in computer architecture?

options.title: It performs mathematical operations
It manages the flow of data between the CPU and peripherals
It translates virtual addresses to physical addresses for efficient memory access

questions.title: What is the difference between Harvard architecture and Von Neumann architecture?

options.title: Harvard architecture has separate memory for data and instructions, while Von Neumann architecture uses a single memory space
Harvard architecture uses a single memory space, while Von Neumann architecture has separate memory for data and instructions
Harvard architecture is a type of caching technique

questions.title: In the context of computer architecture, explain the concept of out-of-order execution.

options.title: It refers to executing instructions in the order they are fetched
It allows executing instructions ahead of the original program order for improved performance
It is a type of error-checking mechanism in the CPU

questions.title: What is encapsulation in OOP?

options.title: Exposing internal implementation details
Bundling data and methods into a single unit
Allowing unrestricted access to class members

questions.title: What is the purpose of the "this" keyword in OOP?

options.title: Referring to the current instance of a class
Creating a new object
Accessing static members of a class

questions.title: In OOP, what is method overloading?

options.title: Defining multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
Creating a method that calls another method
Overriding a method in a subclass

questions.title: What is the purpose of the "super" keyword in OOP?

options.title: Referring to a child class
Calling the constructor of the parent class
Identifying static methods

questions.title: What is the concept of polymorphism in OOP?

options.title: The ability of a function to take different forms or behave differently based on the input
Creating multiple instances of a class
Restricting access to class members

questions.title: Explain the concept of interfaces in OOP.

options.title: A way to implement multiple inheritance in programming languages
A contract specifying a set of methods that a class must implement
A type of data structure in OOP

questions.title: What is the difference between abstraction and encapsulation in OOP?

options.title: Abstraction is a way to hide the complexity of the implementation, while encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods.
Abstraction is the bundling of data and methods, while encapsulation is a way to hide the complexity of the implementation.
Abstraction and encapsulation are synonymous in OOP.

questions.title: What is the purpose of abstract classes in OOP?

options.title: To create classes without any methods
To prevent instantiation and provide a base for other classes
To hide the implementation details of a class

questions.title: Explain the concept of covariance and contravariance in the context of OOP.

options.title: Covariance is the ability to assign an object of a derived class to a variable of the base class, and contravariance is the opposite.
Covariance and contravariance refer to the same concept in OOP.
Covariance is the ability to assign an object of the base class to a variable of the derived class, and contravariance is the opposite.

questions.title: What is the role of design patterns in OOP, and provide an example of a commonly used design pattern.

options.title: Design patterns define the layout of graphical user interfaces; an example is the Observer pattern.
Design patterns are best practices for structuring code; an example is the Singleton pattern.
Design patterns are used for encryption algorithms; an example is the Strategy pattern.

questions.title: What is software design?

options.title: The process of coding a program
The process of creating a blueprint for a software solution
The process of testing a software application

questions.title: What is the purpose of UML (Unified Modelling Language) in software design?

options.title: To write code
To model and visualise software systems
To manage project schedules

questions.title: What is the role of architectural patterns in software design?

options.title: They define the high-level structure and behaviour of a software system
They focus on optimising algorithms
They are only relevant during the coding phase

questions.title: What is the difference between monolithic and micro services architecture?

options.title: Monolithic architecture is modular, while micro-services architecture is a single, unified structure
Micro-services architecture divides the application into small, independent services, while monolithic architecture is a single, unified structure
Both terms refer to the same architectural style

questions.title: What is the SOLID principles in software design?

options.title: A set of principles for writing maintainable and scalable software
A set of guidelines for choosing software development tools
A set of rules for optimising database queries

questions.title: Explain the concept of a design pattern in software architecture.

options.title: A reusable solution to common problems that occur in software design
A specific set of colors and fonts used in the user interface

questions.title: What is the role of the Dependency Injection pattern in software design?

options.title: It helps manage database connections
It allows for the inversion of control, facilitating the creation and management of object dependencies

questions.title: What is the difference between horizontal and vertical scaling in the context of software architecture?

options.title: Horizontal scaling involves adding more machines to a network, while vertical scaling involves adding more resources to a single machine
Horizontal scaling involves adding more resources to a single machine, while vertical scaling involves adding more machines to a network
Both terms refer to the same concept in software architecture

questions.title: Explain the concept of event-driven architecture in software design.

options.title: It involves optimising algorithms based on user events
It is an architectural style where components communicate by events triggered by external actions
It is a method for designing database schemas

questions.title: In the context of software architecture, what is the significance of the CAP theorem?

options.title: It defines the principles of database normalisation
It explores the trade-offs between consistency, availability, and partition tolerance in distributed systems
It is a framework for evaluating the efficiency of algorithms

questions.title: What is the purpose of a version control system (VCS) in software development?

options.title: To track changes in the hardware
To manage and track changes in the source code
To optimize database queries

questions.title: What is the role of a compiler in the software construction process?

options.title: To translate source code into machine code
To execute the program
To manage project schedules

questions.title: What is the significance of unit testing in software construction?

options.title: To verify the correctness of individual units or components
To test the entire system as a whole

questions.title: What is the purpose of a coding standard in software development?

options.title: To enforce a consistent style and improve code readability
To specify the hardware requirements for a program
To limit creativity in coding

questions.title: What is the role of a static code analyzer in the software construction process?

options.title: To identify runtime errors
To optimize database performance
To analyze source code without executing it, finding potential issues

questions.title: Explain the concept of continuous integration in software development.

options.title: It involves automatically integrating code changes from multiple developers into a shared repository frequently
It refers to a one-time integration of code before deployment
It is a method for optimizing SQL queries

questions.title: What is the difference between agile and waterfall software development methodologies?

options.title: Agile and waterfall are two terms for the same methodology
Agile focuses on iterative development and flexibility, while waterfall follows a linear, sequential approach
Agile is a method for hardware development, while waterfall is for software development

questions.title: In the context of software construction, what is the significance of the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle?

options.title: It encourages redundancy in code for better understanding
It promotes code reusability by avoiding duplication
It discourages using comments in the code

questions.title: What is the role of design patterns in software construction?

options.title: Design patterns are templates for graphical user interfaces
Design patterns are reusable solutions to common problems in software design
Design patterns are only applicable in the testing phase

questions.title: Explain the concept of pair programming in software development.

options.title: It involves writing code individually without collaboration
It is a method for database schema design
It is a practice where two programmers work together at one workstation, with one typing and the other reviewing and providing feedback

questions.title: What is a primary key in a database?

options.title: A unique identifier for a record in a table
A table that stores only primary data
An index for speeding up query performance

questions.title: What is the purpose of the SQL SELECT statement?

options.title: To insert data into a table
To retrieve data from a database
To update existing records in a table

questions.title: In the context of database normalisation, what is the goal of the Third Normal Form (3NF)?

options.title: To eliminate data redundancy
To ensure referential integrity
To create composite keys

questions.title: What is the purpose of an index in a database table?

options.title: To define the primary key
To enforce data integrity constraints
To improve query performance by facilitating faster data retrieval

questions.title: Explain the concept of ACID properties in database transactions.

options.title: A set of properties that ensure atomicity, consistency, isolation, and durability of transactions
A mechanism for encrypting data in the database
A method for optimising query execution plans

questions.title: What is the role of a foreign key in a relational database?

options.title: To uniquely identify each record in a table
To establish a link between two tables based on a common attribute
To enforce primary key constraints

questions.title: What is the difference between a clustered and a non-clustered index in a database?

options.title: A clustered index determines the physical order of data, while a non-clustered index does not affect the physical order.
A non-clustered index determines the physical order of data, while a clustered index does not affect the physical order.
Both terms are synonymous and can be used interchangeably.

questions.title: Explain the concept of database sharing.

options.title: It is a process of encrypting database tables for security purposes
It involves dividing a large database into smaller, more manageable parts called shards to improve performance and scalability
It is a method for defining complex queries in SQL

questions.title: What is the purpose of a database view?

options.title: To physically store data in the database
To create a virtual table that is based on the result of a SELECT query
To enforce data integrity constraints

questions.title: In the context of database security, what is the principle of least privilege?

options.title: It refers to granting users the maximum level of access to the database
It is the practice of providing users with the minimum level of access required to perform their tasks
